definition:
Topological space $X$ is called *Alexandroff* if the intersection of
every family of open sets is open.

Of course every finite topological space is Alexandroff, but there are
also bigger Alexandroff spaces. For example let $\mathbb{R}$ denote the
set of real numbers and let
$\tau=\{[a,\infty)\ |\ a\in\mathbb{R}\} \cup \{(b,\infty)\ |\ b\in\mathbb{R}\}$.
Then $\tau$ is a topology on $\mathbb{R}$ and $(\mathbb{R},\tau)$ is an
Alexandroff space.

If $X$ is an Alexandroff space and $A\subseteq X$, then we may talk
about smallest open neighbourhood of $A$. Indeed, let
$$A^{o}=\bigcap \{U\subseteq X\ |\ U\mbox{ is open and }A\mbox{ is contained in }U\}.$$
Then $A^{o}$ is open.
